text:
14th Street, east from 120 West 14th Street, the view cut off by the Sixth Avenue Elevated, after the famous blizzard of 1888. The building on the left occupies the site where the Ninth Regiment Armory is to be erected five years later.
March, 1888.
Ewing Galloway.

14th Street east from but not including Sixth Avenue, from about 56 and 57 West 14th Street.  The church at the left, of which only a glimpse is visible, is the Scotch Presbyterian Church.
About 1892.

Brown Brothers.

[Additional note, in the right hand portion of the frame you can see the original R.H. Macy & Co. building before it moved in 1902 to 34th & Broadway.]

W. 14th Street, north side, west of Sixth Avenue, showing the 14th Street Theatre and the Ninth Regiment Armory.  This theatre, opened May, 1866 as the Theatre Francais, was demolished in the Spring of 1938.  The Armory still stands.  Its date of construction was 1892-3.
About 1900
Ewing Galloway

West 14th Street, west from Sixth Avenue.  At the right is the 14th Street Theatre.  Adjoining same is the 9th Regiment Armory. The photographer's vantage point is|the Sixth Avenue "El".  View 2, taken at a later date includes the Salvation Army Memorial Bldg. at the left, and the Lawyers Trust Bldg. in the background.

The theatre was opened in 1866 as the Theatre Francaise [sic].  It was rebuilt in 1871 as the Lyceum. Subsequently it was the 14th Street and the Civic Repertory (1926).  It was demolished in 1939.

The Ninth Regiment can be traced back to 1812.  In 1848 it was re-organized, as an Irish regiment, and disbanded a few years later.  In 1859 it was again reformed.  In 1861, the entire command went to Washington, independently, and was sworn into the United States service for three years.  They formed the 83rd New York Volunteers, seeing service in the Wilderness, at Antietam, Fredericksburg, the second Bull Run, and Gettysburg.  Between 1870 and 1872 James Fisk was the colonel of the Ninth.  The armory was built by the City in 1893 at a cost of $300,000, plus land at $422,000.

1: April 1906
2: June 23, 1937

View 1: George L. Balgue, photo
View 2: W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project

Old Douglas Mansion, 128 West 14th Street, south side, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, at the end of its long career.  See the view about 1918, by Ewing Galloway.
June, 1925.

Old Cruger or Douglas Mansion, 128 West 14th Street, south side, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.  Originally built as a reproduction of Boscobel House, the Douglas family nest in Scotland, it has had a long and varied history.  Louis Kossuth, the Hungarian patriot, stayed here in 1851.  Theodore Roosevelt the Elder played here as a boy.  From 1873 to 1879 it was occupied by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.  Then it became a saloon, and finally ended its days as the Salvation Army training college, like a tired old man turning to religion at the end of a colorful life.
About 1918.
Ewing Galloway.

14th Street, intersection 6th Avenue,(Before Reconstruction).

March 21, 1920.

6th Avenue, East Side Intersection at 14th Street. (Before Reconstruction)
May 21, 1922.

131 West 14th Street, north side, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. About 1922.

Gift of E.M. Jenks.

14th Street east from but not including Sixth Avenue, the companion picture to Brown Brothers' 1892 view, but taken from a little nearer Sixth Avenue and thus showing 59 and 61 West 14th Street on the north side.
1926.
Brown Brothers.

(3 & 4)
A more inclusive view eastward to Sixth Ave. and showing the elevated line thereon. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.

According to the New York Times of April 1, 1938 the theatre shown will be demolished and replaced with a modern motion picture house. This structure opened in 1866 as the Theatre Francais, was rebuilt in 1871 and named the Lyceum, later to become the 14th Street Theatre.  For a fuller account see either the above newspaper or Kings Handbook of New York published in 1892.

According to the New York Times of April 1, 1938 the theatre shown will be demolished and replaced with a modern motion picture house. This structure opened in 1866 as the Theatre Francais, was rebuilt in 1871 and named the Lyceum, later to become the 14th Street Theatre.  For a fuller account see either the above newspaper or Kings Handbook of New York published in 1892.

14th Street, at the N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue ("El" thereon and which will shortly be razed). The vacant plot at the left was the site of the former Civic Repertory Theatre and upon which will rise a modern neighborhood motion-picture house.

This building was opened in 1866 as the Theatre Francaise [sic], and during the first year Jacob Grau presented Ristori there in her American premiere. The house was rebuilt in 1871 and renamed the Lyceum. As time passed, the type of productions changed , tho at one time it was a center of the social and dramatic life.

It became the 14th Street Theatre later and since 1926, the Civic Repertory Theatre. The New York Times of April 1, 1938 carried an article to the above effect.

June 16, 1938.

P.L. Sperr

6th Avenue, east side, adjoining the northeast corner of 14th St.

P. L. Sperr
May 17, 1939

6th Ave. at 14th St. from 15th St. March 29, 1939.
P.L. Sperr, photographer

W. 14th Street, adjoining the N. W. corner of Sixth Avenue. The Civic Repertory Theatre is under demolition and the photographer shows items found in the debris.

1939
Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

W. 14th Street, adjoining the N. W. corner of Sixth Avenue. Among the debris shown are the columns and ornamentation of the Civic Repertory Theatre.
